New Adult Nonfiction Books

New Arrivals Added To Our Adult Nonfiction Collection
URL: http://money.mcpl.info/new-arrivals
Updated: 1 day 6 min ago

Managing money by Bostick, Nan.

Mon, 04/30/2012 - 3:01am

Martha's American food : a celebration of our nation's most treasured dishes, from coast to coast by Stewart, Martha.

Mon, 04/30/2012 - 3:01am

In this love letter to American food, Martha Stewart, who has so significantly influenced the American table, collects her most favorite national dishes, as well as the stories and traditions behind them. These are recipes that will delight you with nostalgia, inspire you, and teach you about our nation by way of its regions and their distinctive flavors. Above all, these are time-honored recipes that you will turn to again and again. Organized geographically, the 200 recipes in "Martha's Americ

Medusa by Hirschmann, Kris, 1967-

Mon, 04/30/2012 - 3:01am

Desribes the history of the legend of Medusa, including the ancient Greek myth of Perseus and the Gorgons, representations of Medusa in art, and modern versions of the monster in popular culture.

Memoirs of a rugby-playing man : guts, glory, and blood in the world's greatest game by Atkinson, Jay, 1957-

Mon, 04/30/2012 - 3:01am

Midnight in Peking : how the murder of a young Englishwoman haunted the last days of old China by French, Paul, 1966-

Mon, 04/30/2012 - 3:01am

Historian and China expert Paul French uncovers the truth behind the notorious murder of Pamela Werner, and offers a rare glimpse of the last days of colonial Peking.

Mike Wallace : a life by Rader, Peter.

Mon, 04/30/2012 - 3:01am

The untold story of how the world's most feared TV reporter transformed his inner darkness into a journalistic juggernaut that riveted millions and redefined the landscape of television news In his four decades as the front man for "60 Minutes."

More powerful than dynamite : radicals, plutocrats, progressives, and New York's year of anarchy by Jones, Thai, 1977-

Mon, 04/30/2012 - 3:01am

My happy days in Hollywood by Marshall, Garry.

Mon, 04/30/2012 - 3:01am

A lighthearted account by the producer and director of such productions as "Laverne & Shirley" and "Pretty Woman" traces his Bronx childhood, role in shaping A-list celebrity careers, and personal philosophies about life and entertainment.

Nova Scotia by Hempstead, Andrew.

Mon, 04/30/2012 - 3:01am

Oklahoma City by Gumbel, Andrew.

Mon, 04/30/2012 - 3:01am

Combining groundbreaking investigative research with a shocking and true conspiracy story, investigative journalists Andrew Gumbel and Roger Charles puncture the myth about what happened on April 19, 1995 at the Alfred P. Murrah Federal Building. "Oklahoma City" reveals that more players were involved in the plot than simply Timothy McVeigh and Terry Nichols.

On the run in Siberia by Willerslev, Rane, 1971-

Mon, 04/30/2012 - 3:01am

Online gaming and entertainment by Marcovitz, Hal.

Mon, 04/30/2012 - 3:01am

Discusses the issues surrounding online gaming and entertainment, including onling gaming addiction, online gambling, and legislation regarding online entertainment.

Online information and research by Marcovitz, Hal.

Mon, 04/30/2012 - 3:01am

This book examines the benefits and risks of using the internet to perform research.

Online privacy by Currie, Stephen, 1960-

Mon, 04/30/2012 - 3:01am

Discusses privacy issues in the digital age including privacy in social networks, in corporations, and in government.

Online security by Mooney, Carla, 1970-

Mon, 04/30/2012 - 3:01am

Discusses online security in the digital age, including the risk of identity theft, Internet attacks on corporate networks, and cyberterrorism, and describes methods to help secure online information both currently and in the future.

Paris, I love you but you're bringing me down by Baldwin, Rosecrans.

Mon, 04/30/2012 - 3:01am

A people's guide to Los Angeles by Pulido, Laura.

Mon, 04/30/2012 - 3:01am

Permanent emergency : inside the TSA and the fight for the future of security by Hawley, Edmund S. (Edmund Summers), 1953-

Mon, 04/30/2012 - 3:01am

"Since 2001 the TSA has accepted responsibility for protecting over two million people a day at U.S. airports and managing transportation operations around the world. But how effective is this beleaguered agency, and is it really keeping us safe from terrorism? In this riveting expose, former TSA administrator Kip Hawley reveals the secrets behind the agency's ongoing battle to outthink and outmaneuver terrorists, illuminating the flawed, broken system that struggles to stay one step ahead of ca

Prague winter : a personal story of remembrance and war, 1937-1948 by Albright, Madeleine Korbel.

Mon, 04/30/2012 - 3:01am

From former Secretary of State Madeleine Albright comes a moving and thoughtful memoir of her formative years in Czechoslovakia during the tumult of Nazi occupation, World War II, fascism, and the onset of the Cold War.

Renegades by Ward, Robert, 1943-

Mon, 04/30/2012 - 3:01am

After spending time as a professor in upstate New York, Robert Ward decided to give journalism a try. What followed were two decades of assignments for New Times , GQ , SPORT , Rolling Stone , and other publications, covering the biggest stars of the sporting, music, art, and film worlds. This collection includes Ward's celebrated story on Reggie Jackson that nearly tore the New York Yankees apart (and was later brought to life in an ESPN miniseries "The Bronx Is Burning"); a profile of the "out
